facts.text: House No. 11, Kaiserbagh at Lucknow, was since 1918 in the occupation of one Chowdhry Akbar Hussain.

anchor.surface_text: House No. 11, Kaiserbagh at Lucknow, was since 1918 in the occupation of one Chowdhry Akbar Hussain. After the partition of India, Chowdhry Akbar Hussain migrated to Pakistan.

facts.text: Chowdhry Akbar Hussain migrated to Pakistan after the partition of India.

anchor.surface_text: After the partition of India, Chowdhry Akbar Hussain migrated to Pakistan. By order dated October 12, 1949 the Deputy Custodian of Evacuee Property, Lucknow, in exercise of power under s. 6 of the U. P. Administration of Evacuee Property Ordinance 1 of 1949

facts.text: By order dated October 12, 1949 the Deputy Custodian of Evacuee Property, Lucknow, declared No. 11, Kaiserbagh as evacuee property under s. 6 of the U. P. Administration of Evacuee Property Ordinance 1 of 1949 as continued in force by Central Ordinances 12 and 20 of 1949.

anchor.surface_text: By order dated October 12, 1949 the Deputy Custodian of Evacuee Property, Lucknow, in exercise of power under s. 6 of the U. P. Administration of Evacuee Property Ordinance 1 of 1949 as continued in force by Central Ordinances 12 and 20 of 1949 declared No. 11, Kaiserbagh as evacuee property.

facts.text: No claim was preferred by any person in pursuance of this notification.

anchor.surface_text: No claim was preferred by any person in pursuance of this notification, and management of the property continued with the Custodian of Evacuee Property.

facts.text: Acting under s. 12 of the Displaced Persons Compensation and Rehabilitation Act 44 of 1954, the Central Government by a notification dated May 27, 1955 acquired the property for the Central pool constituted under that Act.

anchor.surface_text: Acting under s. 12 of the Displaced Persons Compensation and Rehabilitation Act 44 of 1954, the Central Government by a notification dated May 27, 1955 acquired the property for the Central pool constituted under that Act.

facts.text: On June 7, 1957 the property was put up for sale by public auction and was purchased by one Ram Chand Kohli.

anchor.surface_text: On June 7, 1957 the property was put up for sale by public auction and was purchased by one Ram Chand Kohli.

facts.text: On September 27, 1961 the State of Uttar Pradesh applied under s. 27 of the Administration of Evacuee Property Act 31 of 1950 invoking the revisional jurisdiction of the Custodian-General against the order of the Deputy Custodian notifying the property as evacuee property.

anchor.surface_text: On September 27, 1961 the State of Uttar Pradesh applied under s. 27 of the Administration of Evacuee Property Act 31 of 1950 invoking the revisional jurisdiction of the Custodian-General against the order of the Deputy Custodian notifying the property as evacuee property.

facts.text: The State of Uttar Pradesh claimed that the property belonged to the State and Chowdhry Akbar Hussain had no proprietary interest in the property.

anchor.surface_text: The State of Uttar Pradesh claimed that the property belonged to the State and Chowdhry Akbar Hussain had no proprietary interest in the property and accordingly the Deputy Custodian had no power to declare it evacuee property.

facts.text: The State of Uttar Pradesh was not aware of the notification declaring the property to be evacuee property, nor of the subsequent proceedings and of the sale to Ram Chand Kohli.

anchor.surface_text: It was submitted that the State of Uttar Pradesh was not aware of the notification declaring the property to be evacuee property, not of the subsequent proceedings and of the sale to Ram Chand Kohli.

facts.text: The appellants who are the legal representatives of Ram Chand Kohli contended that the petition was belated, and that the property being of the ownership of Chowdhry Akbar Hussain it was lawfully declared evacuee property.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants who are the legal representatives of Ram Chand Kohli contended, inter alia, that the petition was belated, and that in any event the property being of the ownership of Chowdhry Akbar Hussain it was lawfully declared evacuee property.

facts.text: The Custodian-General upheld the plea of the State of Uttar Pradesh, and set aside the order of the Deputy Custodian.

anchor.surface_text: The Custodian-General upheld the plea of the State of Uttar Pradesh, and set aside the order of the Deputy Custodian.

facts.text: Appeal by special leave to Supreme Court: Civil Appeal No. 659 of 1964 from judgment and order dated September 11, 1962 of the Custodian General in Revision Petition No. 1209-R UP/1961.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 659 of 1964. Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order, dated the September 11, 1962 of the Custodian General of Evacuee Property, Department of Rehabilitation, Ministry of Works Housing and Supply, New Delhi in Revision Petition No. 1209- R UP/1961.

facts.text: U. P. Administration of Evacuee Property Ordinance 1 of 1949 was promulgated by the Governor of the United Provinces on June 22, 1949.

anchor.surface_text: The U.P. Ordinance 1 of 1949 was promulgated by the Governor of the United Provinces on June 22,1949.

facts.text: Central Ordinance 12 of 1949 called The Administration of Evacuee Property Chief Commissioners Provinces Ordinance, 1949 issued shortly before U.P. Ordinance 1 of 1949.

anchor.surface_text: Shortly before the promulgation of that Ordinance, the Governor-General had in exercise of the powers conferred by S. 42 of the Government of India Act 1935 issued Central Ordinance 12 of 1949 called The Administration of Evacuee Property Chief Commissioners Provinces Ordinance, 1949.

facts.text: Ordinance 20 of 1949 issued on August 23, 1949 applied Ordinance 12 of 1949 to United Provinces.

anchor.surface_text: The Governor-General issued on August 23, 1949 Ordinance 20 of 1949, by S. 4 whereof Ordinance 12 of 1949 was applied to the Provinces of Madras and the United Provinces.

facts.text: Ordinance 27 of 1949 issued on October 18, 1949 repealed Ordinance 12 of 1949.

anchor.surface_text: On October 18, 1949 the Governor-General issued Ordinance 27 of 1949 called The Administration of Evacuee Property Ordinance, 1949.

facts.text: Administration of Evacuee Property Act 31 of 1950 repealed Ordinance 27 of 1949.

anchor.surface_text: This Ordinance 27 of 1949 was repealed by the Administration of Evacuee Property Act 31 of 1950.

facts.text: The Custodian-General had jurisdiction to entertain the revision petition under s. 27 of Act 31 of 1950.

anchor.surface_text: We are therefore of the view that the Custodian-General had the power to entertain the revision application filed by the State of Uttar Pradesh.

facts.text: The procedure followed by the Custodian-General violated rules of natural justice.

anchor.surface_text: The procedure followed by the Custodian-General is in gross violation of the rules of natural justice.

facts.text: Revision petition heard on August 4, 1962 and adjourned to August 14, 1962.

anchor.surface_text: The revision petition was heard by the Custodian-General on August 4, 1962, and thereafter the proceeding stood adjourned till August 14, 1962 for further hearing.

facts.text: On August 6, 1962, counsel for the appellants served a notice upon counsel for the State of Uttar Pradesh calling for inspection of documents.

anchor.surface_text: On August 6, 1962, counsel for the appellants served a notice upon counsel for the State of Uttar Pradesh calling upon him to give inspection of the documents referred to in the notice.

facts.text: No inspection of documents was given to appellants' counsel before hearing on August 14, 1962.

anchor.surface_text: No inspection was given, and the hearing took place on August 14, 1962.

facts.text: Supreme Court sets aside Custodian-General's order and remands for retrial due to breach of natural justice.

issues.text: Whether in a given case, the Custodian-General may entertain a petition against an order passed by a subordinate authority, notwithstanding gross delay in instituting the proceeding

issues.text: whether the Custodian-General had the power to entertain the petition under s. 27 of the Administration of Evacuee Property Act 31 of 1950, challenging the order passed by the Deputy Custodian on October 12, 1949

anchor.surface_text: The question which then must be considered is whether the Custodian-General had the power to entertain the petition under s. 27 of the Administration of Evacuee Property Act 31 of 1950, challenging the order passed by the Deputy Custodian on October 12, 1949.

holdings.text: Whether in a given case, the Custodian-General may entertain a petition against an order passed by a subordinate authority, notwithstanding gross delay in instituting the proceeding is a matter within his discretion.

anchor.surface_text: Whether in a given case, the Custodian-General may entertain a petition against an order passed by a subordinate authority, notwithstanding gross delay in instituting the proceeding is a matter within his discretion. We do not think that in exercise

holdings.reasoning_summary: Delay in filing revision is within Custodian-General's discretion; Supreme Court will not interfere under Art. 136 even if disagreeing.

holdings.text: the Custodian-General had the power to entertain the revision application filed by the State of Uttar Pradesh.

anchor.surface_text: We are therefore of the view that the Custodian-General had the power to entertain the revision application filed by the State of Uttar Pradesh.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Deeming provisions in s.58(3) of 1950 Act and prior ordinances make 1949 order subject to s.27 revision; distinguishes Indira Sohanlal and Dafadar Niranjan; purposive interpretation over s.6 General Clauses Act.

holdings.text: the trial of the petition is vitiated by gross irregularities and breach of the rules of natural justice.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No opportunity given to appellants to inspect documents or rebut new evidence tendered by State.

holdings.text: The procedure followed by the Custodian-General is in gross violation of the rules of natural justice.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Custodian-General admitted new evidence without formal order, denied inspection and rejoinder opportunity despite notice.

holdings.text: the proceedings of the Custodian-General were so wholly inconsistent with the procedure which may be followed in a judicial trial, that his order must be set aside and the proceedings remanded to the Custodian-General

anchor.surface_text: In our view the proceedings of the Custodian-General were so wholly inconsistent with the procedure which may be followed in a judicial trial, that his order must be set aside and the proceedings remanded to the Custodian-General

holdings.reasoning_summary: Violation of natural justice requires setting aside order and remanding for fresh hearing with opportunities to tender evidence and inspect documents.
